questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The GBM is primarily composed of collagen type I and elastin.

options.label: B
options.text: The GBM is a selective barrier between the glomerular capillaries and Bowman's capsule.

options.label: C
options.text: Thickening of the GBM is a characteristic feature of minimal change disease.

options.label: D
options.text: The GBM is impermeable to large molecules such as albumin.

questions.correct_answer: B. The GBM is a selective barrier between the glomerular capillaries and Bowman's capsule.

questions.text: Which of the following kidney findings will be seen in malignant hypertension?

Match the following types of renal crystals with their characteristics Types of Renal Crystals Characteristics 1. Calcium Oxalate Monohydrate A. Coffin lid-shaped crystals, commonly found in alkaline urine 2.. Uric Acid B. Rhomboid-shaped crystals, typically seen in acidic urine. 3. Cystine C. Dumbbell or ovoid-shaped crystals are often colourless in acidic urine. 4. . Struvite (Magnesium Ammonium Phosphate) D. Hexagonal plates, often associated with acidic urine
questions.explanation:
Struvite/ Staghorn stones:

 
  • Radioopaque.
  • Seen in alkaline urine.
  • Rectangular/coffin lid appearance.
  • Associated with urea-splitting organisms.

Cystine Stones

 
  • Radiopaque.
  • Seen in acidic urine.
  • Hexagonal Shaped.
  • Very hard stones.

Calcium Oxalate Monohydrate stones

 
  • Radiopaque.
  • Seen in acidic urine.
  • Dumbell shaped.
  • Most common type of renal calculi.

Uric Acid crystals

 
  • Radiolucent.
  • Seen in acidic urine.
  • Rhomboids or parallelograms.

Ammonium Urate crystals

 
  • Radiolucent.
  • Associated with laxative abuse.

questions.text: Match the following renal casts with the conditions they are associated with: Renal Cast Type Condition Associated 1. Hyaline casts A. Nephrotic syndrome 2. Granular casts B. Chronic Renal Failure 3. Waxy casts C. Acute tubular necrosis 4. Fatty casts D. Fever
questions.explanation:
Renal Cast Type

Condition Associated

 Images

Hyaline casts

Normal conditions, Fever, Pregnancy

Muddy Brown/ granular casts

Acute tubular necrosis

Waxy casts

Chronic renal failure

Fatty casts

Nephrotic syndrome

RBC casts

Glomerulonephritis

WBC casts

Pyelonephritis, interstitial nephritis

Epithelial casts

Renal epithelial injury

Broad casts

Chronic renal disease

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic male presented to the hospital complaining of chronic abdominal discomfort and unexplained weight loss over the past few months. A palpable firm mass was detected on the left upper quadrant upon physical examination. Ultrasound revealed a large mass in the left upper pole of the kidney. Due to suspicion of renal malignancy, the patient underwent a left nephrectomy. Based on the specimen obtained, what is the most likely diagnosis?
A renal biopsy specimen has to be examined under microscopy for the presence of nephroblastoma. Presence of which of the following findings is less likely suggestive of the same?
questions.explanation:
Characteristics

Wilms Tumor

Neuroblastoma

Location
  • Kidney
  • Most common abdominal tumor in childhood
  • Common site: adrenal medulla,
  • Also seen in abdomen, pelvis & neck.
  • Most common primary renal tumor in childhood.

Histological features
  • Blastemal: Small blue cells. (Option B ruled out)
  • Epithelial: Abortive tubules/glomeruli.
  • Stromal: Fibroblastic or myxoid. (Option D ruled out)
  • Small blue cells with neuroblasts,
  • neurofibrils (neuropils) (Option A), and mature ganglion cells
  • Pseudo-rosettes (arrangements of small, round neuroblastic cells around a central fibrillary core)
Histological image

 

 

Type

Examples

Renal Tumors
  • Wilms Tumor (Nephroblastoma)
  • Renal Cell Carcinoma
  • Renal Lymphoma

Adrenal Tumors
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Adrenal Hemangioma

Hepatic Tumors
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Hemangioma

GI conditions
  • Neuroendocrine Tumors
  • Intestinal Malrotation
  • Meckel’s Diverticulum
  • Hirschsprung’s Disease

Lymphoma
  • Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma
  • Hodgkin’s lymphoma
  • Lymphoblastic lymphoma

Teratoma
  • Ovarian Teratoma
  • Testicular Teratoma
  • Retroperitoneal Teratoma

Mesenteric and Omental masses
  • Mesenteric Adenitis
  • Mesenteric Cyst
  • Lymphangioma

Vascular Tumors
  • Hemangiomas (Hepatic, Cutaneous)
  • Lymphangiomas
  • Angiomyolipomas

Pancreatic masses
  • Pancreatic Pseudocyst

Abdominal Cysts
  • Choledochal Cyst
  • Ovarian Cysts

Inflammatory Conditions
  • Appendicitis (with abscess)
  • Crohn’s Disease
  • Ulcerative Colitis
  • Cystic Fibrosis

questions.text: A histopathological report of renal biopsy done on a child states, “tumour cells suggestive of nephroblastoma along with adjacent sclerotic rests”. What is the risk associated with the presence of such sclerotic rests?
Which of the following statements regarding renal cell carcinoma is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Clear cell RCC is the most common type overall.

options.label: B
options.text: Papillary RCC is most commonly associated with dialysis patients.

options.label: C
options.text: Medullary RCC is commonly seen in sickle cell trait patients.

options.label: D
options.text: Papillary RCC has the best prognosis.

questions.correct_answer: D. Papillary RCC has the best prognosis.
questions.explanation:
Age group
  • Most common in the 6th and 7th decades.

Male: Female ratio
  • 2:1

Site of origin
  • Proximal convoluted tubule.

Risk factors
  • Cigarette smoking (most important).
  • Obesity (particularly in women) and hypertension.
  • Unopposed estrogen therapy.
  • Exposure to asbestos, petroleum products, and heavy metals.
  • End-stage renal disease.
  • Chronic kidney disease.
  • Acquired cystic disease.
  • Tuberous sclerosis.

Classification
  • Sporadic: Most common type.
  • Hereditary: Autosomal dominant, young age affected.
    • Von-Hippel-Lindau syndrome.
    • Hereditary leiomyomatosis & renal cell cancer syndrome.
    • Hereditary papillary carcinoma.
    • Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome.
  • Histological classification:
    • Clear cell carcinoma (most common type) (Option A ruled out).
    • Papillary cell carcinoma (associated with dialysis patients) (Option B ruled out).
    • Chromophobe carcinoma (best prognosis) (Option D).
    • Bellini duct (collecting duct) carcinoma.
    • Xp11 translocation carcinoma.
    • Medullary carcinoma (seen in patients with sickle cell trait) (Option C ruled out).

questions.text: On histological examination, which of the following types of renal cell carcinoma shows large cells with a plant-cell-like appearance with a perinuclear halo?
Multiple losses of entire chromosomes are seen in which type of Renal Cell Carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Type of RCC

Causes

 Microscopy Features

Clear Cell RCC (Option B)

Associated with mutations in the VHL gene (von Hippel-Lindau syndrome)

Cells with clear cytoplasm due to the accumulation of glycogen and lipids

 

Papillary RCC (Option A)

Associated with-

  • MET gene mutations
  • Hereditary Leiomyomatosis RCC
  • Dialysis-related cystic disease
  • Loss of Y

Psammoma bodies may be present


 

Chromophobe RCC

Associated with Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome

Loss of multiple chromosomes (Option C) (hypodiploidy)
  • Cells with pale, eosinophilic cytoplasm, Perinuclear halos- Plant cells
  • Hale’s colloidal iron +ve

 

Collecting Duct (Bellini Duct) RCC

Associated with mutations in multiple genes, including SMARCB1

Hobnail cells seen.

Worst prognosis.

Medullary RCC

Strongly associated with sickle cell trait.

Poorly differentiated cells

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of SLE presents with fatigue, decreased urine output, and facial swelling. Lab tests show elevated serum creatinine, proteinuria, and hematuria. A renal biopsy is performed, and the histopathological examination image is attached. Which statement is true regarding this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: >50% of glomeruli showing crescents is diagnostic.

options.label: B
options.text: More the number of crescents, better the prognosis.

options.label: C
options.text: Crescents are composed solely of endothelial cells.

questions.correct_answer: A. >50% of glomeruli showing crescents is diagnostic.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with edema, hypertension, significant proteinuria, and hematuria. Kidney biopsy reveals mesangial and endocapillary hypercellularity with mesangial and subendothelial electron-dense deposits, tram track appearance on silver stains and granular staining for IgG and C3 on Immunofluorescence. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Pathology

Light Microscope

Electron Microscope

Immunofluorescence

Type I MPGN

(Option A)

Mesangial proliferative or membranoproliferative patterns of proliferation; GBM thickening and

Splitting.

(Double-contour or tram track appearance)

Subendothelial and mesangial deposits

IgG ++ C3 (C1q ++ C4 may also present)

Type II MPGN (Dense Deposit Disease)

(Option B)

Dense intramembranous deposits

C3; no C1q or C4

Membranous Nephropathy

(Option C)

Diffuse capillary wall thickening

Subepithelial deposits

Granular IgG and C3; diffuse

Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Option D)

Focal and segmental sclerosis and hyalinosis

Effacement of foot processes; epithelial denudation

Focal; IgM + C3 in many cases

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of poorly controlled diabetes presents with worsening kidney function. Upon examination, renal biopsy reveals glomerular changes consistent with diabetic nephropathy. Which histological findings would be least likely to be observed in the glomeruli of this patient's kidney biopsy?
